title: MoM: Linear Sequence Modeling with Mixture-of-Memories
author: Jusen Du (Shanghai AI Laboratory), Weigao Sun (Shanghai AI Laboratory), Disen Lan (Shanghai AI Laboratory), Jiaxi Hu (The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology), Yu Cheng (The Chinese University of Hong Kong), ..., Jiaxi Hu (The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology)
relevance_why: The approach of utilizing multiple independent memory states could inspire similar methodologies for handling sequence information in audio and speech tasks.
background: The paper explores the effectiveness of memory management in linear sequence models by enhancing their recall capabilities through a mixture-of-memories approach.
contribution: This paper introduces a novel architecture called Mixture-of-Memories to solve the problem of memory interference in linear sequence models, achieving improved performance on recall-intensive tasks.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing linear sequence models suffer from memory interference due to compressing full sequences into a single memory state, limiting their recall capacity.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves upon prior models by integrating multiple independent memory states that can be selectively activated, mitigating interference and enhancing recall capability.

key_innovation: The unique use of a router network to selectively activate multiple memory states based on input significance allows the model to better retain diverse information.
real_world_impact: This method could significantly improve models used in applications that require strong memory and recall abilities, such as conversational AI and long-form content understanding.
limitations: No explicit limitations were mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.memory interference: **Memory interference** refers to the phenomenon where newly learned information disrupts the retrieval of previously stored information, leading to degraded memory performance.

open_sourcing: The code is released at https://github.com/OpenSparseLLMs/MoM
